BUCK.description: The voltage on this pin determines if the IC is regulating the V LOW or V HIGH voltage/current. Float or tie this pin to V5 to select buck mode and to ground to select boost mode operation. This pin has an internal pull up resistor that defaults to buck mode if left floating.

connected_components.description: The internal 5V regulator output from the LTC7871. Connecting BUCK to V5 selects buck mode.
System Ground. Connecting BUCK to SGND selects boost mode.
An internal pull-up resistor to V5 exists on the BUCK pin, causing it to default to buck mode if left floating.

implementation.connectivity: The BUCK pin should be connected to V5 for buck mode operation or to SGND for boost mode operation. It can also be left floating, which defaults to buck mode operation.
implementation.detailed_description: The BUCK pin is used to control the operating mode of the LTC7871, allowing for seamless switching between buck and boost modes of operation. It acts as a digital input that selects between these two power conversion topologies.
implementation.functionality:
The BUCK pin serves two distinct functions based on its electrical connection:
1. Buck Mode Operation: When the BUCK pin is tied to V5 (the internal 5V regulator output) or left floating (due to an internal pull-up resistor), the LTC7871 operates in buck mode. In this mode, power is delivered from V_HIGH to V_LOW.
2. Boost Mode Operation: When the BUCK pin is tied to SGND (ground), the LTC7871 operates in boost mode. In this mode, power is delivered from V_LOW to V_HIGH.
implementation.precautions: When transitioning between buck and boost modes, the internal soft-start is reset, and the ITH pins are parked at their zero current levels to ensure a smooth transition. It is recommended to program SETCUR to its zero current level before switching between modes to further minimize transients.

BUCK.name: BUCK

CLKOUT.description: Clock Output Pin. Use this pin to synchronize multiple LTC7871 ICs. Signal swing is from V5 to ground.

implementation.connected_components: Typically connected to the SYNC pin of other LTC7871 ICs. A short trace is recommended for synchronization integrity.
implementation.connectivity: Connect this pin to the SYNC pin of other LTC7871 ICs to daisy-chain them for synchronization.
implementation.detailed_description: The CLKOUT pin is a clock output pin used to synchronize multiple LTC7871 ICs. The signal swing is from V5 to ground.
implementation.functionality: The primary function is to output a clock signal that can be used to synchronize other LTC7871 ICs in a multi-phase system.
implementation.precautions: When paralleling multiple ICs, ensure the input impedance of the SYNC pin is considered. Keep the PCB trace short and clean to maintain signal integrity for synchronization.

CLKOUT.name: CLKOUT

CSB.description: 4-Wire Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI). Active low chip select (CSB), serial clock (SCLK) and serial data in (SDI) are digital Inputs. Serial data out (SDO) is an open-drain NMOS output pin. SDO requires an external pull-up resistor. Refer to the Serial Port section for more details.

implementation.connected_components: CSB is typically connected to the SPI master's chip select output pin. In a multidrop system, it will be connected to the chip select output of the micro-controller or other SPI master device. An external pull-up resistor to V5 is recommended if the master device cannot guarantee a high level on the CSB pin when deselected, especially in multidrop configurations where SDO might be shared.
implementation.connectivity: CSB should be connected to the master SPI device's chip select output. In a multidrop configuration, each LTC7871 should have its own CSB line controlled independently by the master to select the specific device for communication.
implementation.detailed_description: CSB (Chip Select Bar) is a digital input that enables or disables the serial peripheral interface (SPI) communication with the LTC7871. When CSB is low, the SPI port is active and ready to receive commands or data. When CSB is high, the SPI port is disabled, and the SDO pin is in a high-impedance (Hi-Z) state, allowing for multidrop configurations.
implementation.functionality: The CSB pin functions as an active-low chip select for the SPI interface. When asserted low, it selects the LTC7871 for SPI communication. When de-asserted high, it deselects the device, placing the SDO pin in a high-impedance state.
implementation.precautions: The CSB pin must be driven low to enable SPI communication. Ensure that only one CSB line is asserted low at any time when communicating with multiple LTC7871 devices on the same SPI bus to avoid bus contention. If the SPI master does not drive the CSB line high when deselected, an external pull-up resistor to V5 is recommended to ensure the SPI port is properly disabled and the SDO pin is in a high-impedance state.

CSB.name: CSB

DRVCC.description: Gate Driver Current Supply LDO Output. The voltage on this pin can be set to 5V, 8V, or 10V by the DRVSET pin. Bypass this pin to ground plane with a minimum of 4.7μF low ESR tantalum or ceramic capacitor.

connected_components.connection_description: The DRVCC pin directly powers the external gate drivers for the top and bottom MOSFETs.
A bypass capacitor (minimum 4.7μF, low ESR tantalum or ceramic) is connected between the DRVCC pin and the ground plane to ensure a stable power supply for the internal circuitry and drivers.
The DRVSET pin is used to set the output voltage of the DRVCC LDO. It has internal pull-up and pull-down resistors.
The EXTVCC pin serves as an alternative input to the internal LDO that supplies DRVCC. If EXTVCC is higher than the switchover threshold, it will supply power to DRVCC.

implementation.connectivity: The DRVCC pin should be connected to the power input of the external gate drivers. It needs to be bypassed to a ground plane with a minimum of a 4.7μF low ESR tantalum or ceramic capacitor. The voltage on this pin is controlled by the DRVSET pin.
implementation.detailed_description: The DRVCC pin is the output of an internal Gate Driver Current Supply LDO. This pin provides power to the external top and bottom MOSFET drivers, which are essential for controlling the switching of the power MOSFETs. The voltage at the DRVCC pin can be adjusted externally via the DRVSET pin.
implementation.functionality: The DRVCC pin serves as the power supply for the MOSFET drivers. Its output voltage is programmable to 5V, 8V, or 10V, depending on the setting of the DRVSET pin. The DRVCC pin's power can be supplied either from the VHIGH rail (through an internal LDO) or from the EXTVCC pin, whichever is higher and selected by the DRVSET pin.
precautions: The DRVCC pin voltage is critical for the proper operation of the MOSFET drivers. Ensure the voltage is set correctly using the DRVSET pin according to the MOSFET requirements.
Adequate bypassing is essential to prevent noise from affecting the driver circuitry and the controller itself.
The DRVCC pin has an undervoltage lockout (UVLO) threshold. If the voltage falls below this threshold, the controller will shut down.
Do not exceed the Absolute Maximum Ratings for the DRVCC pin and its related supply pins (EXTVCC).

DRVCC.name: DRVCC

DRVSET.description: The voltage setting on this pin programs the DRV CC output voltage. There are two internal resistors, 200kΩ and 160kΩ, connecting this pin to the V5 and SGND, respectively.

connected_components.description: There are two internal resistors connected to the DRVSET pin. One connects to V5, and the other connects to SGND. These resistors create a voltage divider that sets the DRVCC output voltage.

implementation.connectivity: The DRVSET pin can be connected to SGND, left floating, or connected to V5. The specific connection will determine the DRVCC output voltage.
implementation.detailed_description: The DRVSET pin is used to program the output voltage of the DRVCC pin. The DRVCC pin powers the external MOSFET drivers. The DRVCC voltage can be set to 5V, 8V, or 10V based on the voltage applied to the DRVSET pin.
implementation.functionality: The pin's function is to set the DRVCC output voltage. This is achieved by internal resistors connecting the DRVSET pin to V5 and SGND. The specific voltage levels (5V, 8V, or 10V) are determined by whether the DRVSET pin is tied to SGND, left floating, or tied to V5.
implementation.precautions: The specific voltage levels (5V, 8V, 10V) for DRVCC are achieved through the voltage division created by the internal resistors and the connection of the DRVSET pin. Ensure the desired DRVCC voltage is selected based on the MOSFET driver requirements.

DRVSET.name: DRVSET

EXTVCC.description: External Power Input to an Internal LDO Connected to DRV CC . This LDO supplies DRV CC power, bypassing the internal LDO powered from V HIGH, whenever EXTV CC is higher than its switchover threshold. Do not exceed 60V on this pin.

connected_components.details: A Schottky diode (e.g., with a forward voltage less than 0.5V at the maximum EXTVCC pin current) can be used for protection. It should be connected between the VLOW and EXTVCC pins, or with its cathode connected to EXTVCC and anode connected to ground.
A minimum 1 Ohm resistor in series with the Schottky diode to ground, to limit voltage spikes. The voltage drop across this resistor should be less than 0.5V.

implementation.connectivity: The EXTVCC pin should be connected to an external voltage source. It can be left open or tied to a voltage less than the switchover voltage programmed by the DRVSET pin for DRVCC to be powered from VHIGH. To prevent voltage spikes below ground on the EXTVCC pin, a Schottky diode with a minimum 1 Ohm series resistor (R_FLTR) can be connected from the EXTVCC pin to ground, with the anode connected to ground.
implementation.detailed_description: The EXTVCC pin is the external power input to an internal Linear Regulator (LDO) that is connected to the DRVCC pin. This LDO supplies power to the DRVCC pin. When the voltage on EXTVCC is higher than its switchover threshold, the internal LDO powered from VHIGH is turned off, and the internal LDO powered from EXTVCC is turned on to supply DRVCC power.
implementation.functionality: The EXTVCC pin serves as an alternative input power source for the DRVCC pin. When EXTVCC is above its switchover threshold, it takes over the power supply for DRVCC. Otherwise, DRVCC is powered from VHIGH through an internal LDO.
precautions: Do not exceed 60V on the EXTVCC pin, as this can damage the controller.
When connecting to VLOW, consider using a Schottky diode to prevent voltage spikes below ground on EXTVCC.
Ensure the external voltage source connected to EXTVCC is stable and within the specified range.

EXTVCC.name: EXTVCC

FAULT.description: Fault Indicator Output. Open-drain output that pulls to ground during a fault condition.

connected_components.description: A resistor is required to pull the FAULT pin high when no fault condition is present. The resistor should be connected between the FAULT pin and a voltage supply (e.g., V5). The value of the resistor should be chosen to ensure proper logic level signaling and can be selected based on the desired pull-up current and voltage supply. A common value might be in the range of kOhms.

implementation.connectivity: The FAULT pin is an open-drain output. It should be pulled high with an external resistor connected to a voltage source (e.g., V5 or an external bias voltage) up to 6V.
implementation.detailed_description: The FAULT pin is an open-drain output that indicates a fault condition. It pulls low when certain fault events occur, signaling an issue with the device's operation or a connected system.
implementation.functionality:
The FAULT pin serves as a general fault indicator. It pulls low when any of the following conditions are met:
- The RUN pin is below its turn-on threshold.
- V5 or DRVCC is below its undervoltage lockout (UVLO) threshold.
- Any of the three OV/UV comparators (OVLOW, OVHIGH, UVHIGH) has been tripped.
- During the startup sequence until the SS pin charges up past 1.2V.
- Any channel is in an overcurrent fault status.
- The IC is experiencing over-temperature conditions.
implementation.precautions: Ensure the external pull-up resistor is connected to a voltage source within the absolute maximum ratings of the FAULT pin (up to 6V). When a fault condition occurs, the FAULT pin will be pulled low, so the pull-up resistor should be chosen appropriately to handle this sinking current without exceeding its power rating. The FAULT pin has a delay of 120μs from the fault event until it is pulled low.

FAULT.name: FAULT

FREQ.description: Frequency Set Pin. A resistor between this pin and SGND sets the switching frequency. This pin sources 20µA current.

connected_components.connection: Connected between the FREQ pin and SGND.
connected_components.value_determination: The value is calculated based on the desired switching frequency using the formula provided in the 'Frequency Setting (Standalone)' functionality. For example, to achieve 230kHz, a 51.1kΩ resistor is used.

connected_components.connection: Internally connected to the PLL filter network, with the external connection being to SGND through R_FREQ.
connected_components.purpose: Internal capacitor for the PLL filter network, connected to FREQ and SGND. The datasheet mentions a 20µA current flowing out of the FREQ pin, implying a voltage setting mechanism. The typical application diagrams show various capacitors connected near the FREQ pin, but their specific function in relation to FREQ is not detailed here, beyond the PLL's internal filter. The 'Applications Information' section mentions the filter capacitor holding the voltage in a stable PLL state.

implementation.connectivity: Connect a resistor (R_FREQ) from the FREQ pin to SGND to set the switching frequency. If the SYNC pin is used for synchronization or spread spectrum, the resistor is still required.
implementation.detailed_description: The FREQ pin is used to set the switching frequency of the LTC7871. It sources a precision 20µA current, allowing the switching frequency to be programmed with a single resistor connected to SGND. This pin also interacts with the SYNC pin for frequency synchronization and spread-spectrum modulation.

functionality.description: When the SYNC pin is tied to SGND, a resistor (R_FREQ) connected between the FREQ pin and SGND sets the switching frequency. The relationship between the voltage at the FREQ pin and the switching frequency is defined by: Frequency = V_FREQ – 414kHz/V – 163.5kHz, where V_FREQ = I_FREQ (20µA) * R_FREQ. Alternatively, Frequency = R_FREQ – 8.28kHz/kΩ – 163.5kHz, assuming a perfect 20µA I_FREQ current source.

When the SYNC pin is used to synchronize the LTC7871 to an external clock, the FREQ pin resistor still sets the initial switching frequency before the PLL locks to the external clock. The frequency range for synchronization is 60kHz to 750kHz.
When the SYNC pin is tied to V5 to enable spread spectrum, the FREQ pin resistor still sets the nominal switching frequency. The MFR_SSFM register then controls the spread spectrum parameters.
functionality.function: Spread Spectrum Modulation Control (with SYNC Pin)

precautions: If the SYNC pin is not used for synchronization, ensure it is tied to SGND or V5 as appropriate for the desired operation mode.
When paralleling multiple LTC7871 ICs, the FREQ pins may or may not be tied together. If tied together, account for the combined sourcing currents (20µA per IC) when calculating R_FREQ values.
The SYNC pin has an internal 100kΩ resistor to ground. This should be considered if external components are connected to the SYNC pin.
The resistor on the FREQ pin determines the initial switching frequency, which is crucial for the PLL to lock onto an external clock signal when using the SYNC pin.

FREQ.name: FREQ

ILIM.description: Current Comparator Sense Voltage Limit Selection Pin. The input impedance of this pin is 100kΩ.

connected_components.description: A resistor divider network connected between V5 and SGND is typically used to set a specific voltage on the ILIM pin, thereby selecting the desired current limit. The values of these resistors are chosen based on the desired ILIM voltage level (e.g., 0V, 1/4 V5, Float, 3/4 V5, V5).
The internal 5V regulator output, used as a reference voltage for setting the ILIM pin levels.
Signal Ground, used as the reference for the voltage divider and as the lower potential rail.

implementation.connectivity: The ILIM pin can be connected to ground, V5, or a voltage divider between V5 and SGND to select the desired current limit level. A resistor divider from V5 to SGND is recommended to set the ILIM voltage, ensuring stability across varying conditions. The internal pull-up and pull-down resistors should be considered when designing this divider.
implementation.detailed_description: The ILIM (Current Comparator Sense Voltage Limit Selection Pin) pin is used to set the maximum current limit of the controller. It is a 5-level logic input that influences the Overcurrent Fault Threshold (OCFT) and Negative Overcurrent Fault Threshold (NOCFT). The ILIM pin has an internal 200kΩ pull-down resistor to SGND and a 200kΩ pull-up resistor to V5, providing a default resistance and allowing for voltage division.
implementation.functionality: The ILIM pin's functionality is to set the maximum current limit by selecting one of five different levels. These levels directly correspond to different thresholds for overcurrent and negative overcurrent fault detection. The specific voltage applied to the ILIM pin determines which of these five levels is active. For example, connecting ILIM to ground selects the lowest current sense threshold (10mV for DCR sensing), while connecting it to V5 selects the highest (50mV for DCR sensing).
implementation.precautions: Care must be taken when setting the voltage on the ILIM pin, as it directly impacts the overcurrent protection thresholds. Ensure that the voltage divider resistor values are chosen appropriately to avoid exceeding the absolute maximum ratings of the pin and to achieve the desired current limit. Also, consider the internal pull-up and pull-down resistors when calculating the divider ratios.

ILIM.name: ILIM

IMON.description: Current Monitor Pin. The voltage on this pin is directly proportional to the average inductor currents of all 6 channels. 1.25V on this pin indicates zero average inductor current per phase.

connected_components.details: The IMON pin is internally connected to the output of the current sensing amplifiers and comparators that process signals from the SNSD[+], SNSA[+], and SNS[-] pins. This circuitry calculates the average inductor current.

The IMON pin's voltage output is fed into the inverting input of the current regulation loop error amplifier. This amplifier compares the IMON voltage to the reference voltage provided by the SETCUR pin.
The SETCUR pin provides the reference voltage for the current regulation loop. The voltage on IMON is compared to the voltage derived from the SETCUR pin to regulate the average inductor current.
If the IMON pin is not used, it is recommended to connect it to SGND with a 10kΩ resistor to prevent floating.

implementation.connectivity: The IMON pin should be connected directly to the output of the average inductor current sensing circuitry. In a typical application, this would be a voltage that is proportional to the average inductor current. When multiple LTC7871 ICs are used together, the IMON pins can be tied together to monitor the total average current in the application.
implementation.detailed_description: The IMON pin outputs a voltage that is proportional to the average inductor current of all six channels. A voltage of 1.25V on this pin indicates zero average inductor current per phase. The operational range of IMON is 0.4V to 2.5V. As the inductor current increases in buck mode, the IMON voltage proportionally increases; as the inductor current increases in boost mode, the IMON voltage proportionally decreases. This pin is one of the inputs to the current regulation loop error amplifier, with the SETCUR pin providing the reference.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the IMON pin is to provide a voltage output that is proportional to the average inductor current across all six channels. This voltage serves as feedback for the current regulation loop.
precautions: The operational range of IMON is 0.4V to 2.5V. Ensure that the sensing circuitry and external connections do not cause the IMON voltage to go outside this range, as it may affect the operation of the current regulation loop.

When multiple LTC7871 ICs are used in parallel, tying the IMON pins together allows for monitoring of the total average current. Ensure that the current sensing is accurately shared across all channels.
If the IMON pin is not used, it should be connected to SGND with a 10kΩ resistor to prevent floating and potential noise issues.

IMON.name: IMON

ITHHIGH.description: Current Control Threshold and Error Amplifier Compensation Point. The current comparator’s threshold varies with the ITH control voltage.

connected_components.description: A capacitor is connected from the ITHHIGH pin to SGND. This capacitor is used for soft-start timing and loop compensation. Its value is chosen based on the desired transient response and stability characteristics of the boost converter. Typical values might range from a few nanofarads to tens of nanofarads.

A resistor may be connected in series with the capacitor or directly from ITHHIGH to SGND. This resistor, along with the capacitor, forms an RC network that is crucial for controlling the loop compensation. The resistor value is selected to optimize the bandwidth and phase margin of the control loop. Typical values might range from tens to hundreds of kilohms.

implementation.connectivity: The ITHHIGH pin is connected to the output of the boost error amplifier and the input of the current comparator for boost mode. In a typical application schematic, an external capacitor is connected from ITHHIGH to SGND to set the soft-start time and provide compensation. A resistor may also be connected between ITHHIGH and SGND, or in series with a capacitor, to further shape the control loop's frequency response. In multiphase applications, multiple ITHHIGH pins are typically tied together to ensure current sharing between ICs.
implementation.detailed_description: The ITHHIGH pin serves as the current control threshold and error amplifier compensation point for the boost mode operation of the LTC7871. In boost mode, the voltage on this pin controls the peak inductor current. It is also a critical node for loop compensation, allowing for fine-tuning of the transient response and stability of the boost converter.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of ITHHIGH is to set the current control threshold in boost mode. The voltage at this pin dictates the peak inductor current that the controller aims to achieve. Additionally, it acts as a compensation point for the error amplifier, where external components connected to this pin shape the frequency response of the control loop, influencing stability and transient performance. In buck mode, this pin is typically parked at its zero current level to avoid interference with the buck control loop, unless specific fault conditions override this.
implementation.precautions: It is important to place the compensation components (capacitor and potentially a resistor) connected to the ITHHIGH pin as close as possible to the IC to minimize noise pickup and ensure accurate loop compensation. In multiphase systems, tying the ITHHIGH pins of multiple LTC7871 ICs together is essential for proper current sharing. Care must be taken when setting the compensation components, as incorrect values can lead to instability or poor transient response. Additionally, in fault conditions (e.g., OVHIGH 2.4V threshold), the ITHHIGH pin can be driven into high impedance, which should be accounted for in system design.

ITHHIGH.name: ITHHIGH

ITHLOW.description: Current Control Threshold and Error Amplifier Compensation Point. The current comparator’s threshold varies with the ITH control voltage.

connected_components.description: The ITHLOW pin receives the output voltage from the buck mode error amplifier, which sets the current control threshold.
External components like capacitors and resistors may be connected to the ITHLOW pin to form the loop compensation network for the buck mode.
In a multiphase configuration, the ITHLOW pins of multiple LTC7871 devices are connected together to ensure current sharing.

implementation.connectivity: The ITHLOW pin should be connected to the output of the error amplifier and potentially to external components for loop compensation. In multiphase operation, it should be tied to the ITHLOW pins of other LTC7871 ICs.
implementation.detailed_description: ITHLOW is the current control threshold and error amplifier compensation point for the buck mode operation. The current comparator's threshold varies with the voltage on the ITH pin. In buck mode, the ITHLOW voltage controls the peak inductor current. When the current loop takes over control from the voltage loop, it will take over the ITH pin control from the voltage loop.
implementation.functionality: The ITHLOW pin acts as a control voltage for the current comparator's threshold in buck mode. It is also used as an error amplifier compensation point. In multiphase applications, the ITHLOW pins of multiple LTC7871 ICs should be tied together for proper current sharing. In the event of an OVHIGH 2.4V threshold fault, this pin is driven into high impedance.
implementation.precautions: In case of an OVHIGH 2.4V fault, this pin is driven into high impedance, which may affect system behavior if not accounted for. When paralleling ICs, ensure proper connection of ITHLOW pins for current sharing and that local compensation networks are used for each IC.

ITHLOW.name: ITHLOW

MODE.description: Mode Set Pin. Tying this pin to SGND enables forced continuous mode in buck or boost modes. Floating this pin results in burst mode in buck mode and discontinuous mode in boost mode. Tying this pin to V5 enables discontinuous mode in buck or boost modes. The input impedance of this pin is 90kΩ.

implementation.connectivity: The MODE pin should be connected to either SGND, left floating, or connected to V5, depending on the desired operating mode as described in the 'functionality' section. The input impedance of this pin is 90kΩ.
implementation.detailed_description: The MODE pin is used to select the operating mode of the LTC7871 in terms of discontinuous or continuous conduction mode (DCM/CCM) and Burst Mode operation. This choice influences the efficiency and ripple characteristics of the regulator, particularly at light load conditions.
implementation.functionality:
The MODE pin has three distinct functions based on its connection:

1.  **Forced Continuous Conduction Mode (CCM):** Tying the MODE pin to SGND (ground).
2.  **Burst Mode Operation:** Floating the MODE pin. In buck mode, this results in Burst Mode. In boost mode, this results in Discontinuous Conduction Mode (DCM).
3.  **Discontinuous Conduction Mode (DCM):** Tying the MODE pin to V5 (the internal 5V regulator output).
precautions: Ensure the chosen connection for the MODE pin aligns with the desired operational characteristics (CCM, DCM, or Burst Mode) for both buck and boost modes.

When floating the MODE pin for Burst Mode operation in buck mode, be aware that the inductor current is not allowed to reverse. The reverse current comparator will turn off the bottom MOSFET just before the inductor current reaches zero to prevent negative current.
When selecting DCM operation (MODE pin tied to V5 or floated in boost mode), the controller may exhibit pulse skipping at very light loads, which can lead to larger current and voltage ripple.
The input impedance of the MODE pin is 90kΩ, which should be considered if any external components are connected to it, although typically it is connected directly to a voltage rail or left floating.

MODE.name: MODE

implementation.connectivity: These pins should not be connected to any circuitry in the schematic. They should be left floating.
implementation.detailed_description: The NC pins are 'No Connect' pins. This means they are not connected to any internal circuitry of the LTC7871 and do not have a specific function assigned to them within the IC.
implementation.functionality: These pins have no functionality. They are typically left unconnected or can be used for other purposes on the PCB if available, such as test points or vias to other layers.
implementation.precautions: It is important not to connect any components or traces to the NC pins. Connecting anything to these pins could potentially lead to unexpected behavior or damage to the device, as their internal connections are undefined and not intended for use. In some cases, leaving NC pins unconnected and open can prevent unwanted coupling or noise pickup, but the primary precaution is to simply not connect anything to them.

OVHIGH.description: V HIGH Overvoltage Threshold Set Pin. A resistor divider from V HIGH is needed to set this threshold. When the voltage on this pin rises past the 1.2V trip point, a 5μA current is sourced out of the pin to provide externally adjustable hysteresis.

connected_components.connection_details: A voltage divider formed by two resistors. One resistor connects V HIGH to the OVHIGH pin, and the other connects the OVHIGH pin to SGND. The ratio of these resistors sets the overvoltage threshold.
Connected to the upper resistor of the voltage divider.
Connected to the lower resistor of the voltage divider.

implementation.connectivity: A resistor divider from V HIGH to SGND should be connected to this pin to set the desired overvoltage threshold. The ratio of the resistors in the divider determines the trip point. The OVHIGH pin should be connected to the junction of these resistors.
implementation.detailed_description: The OVHIGH pin is the V HIGH Overvoltage Threshold Set Pin. It is used to set the overvoltage threshold for the V HIGH supply. A resistor divider from V HIGH is needed to set this threshold.
implementation.functionality: The pin serves as an input to an overvoltage comparator. When the voltage on this pin rises past the internal 1.2V trip point, an internal 5µA current is sourced out of the pin to provide externally adjustable hysteresis. This event also triggers a fault condition.
implementation.precautions: The voltage on the OVHIGH pin must be carefully set using the resistor divider to avoid unintended overvoltage shutdowns or to ensure proper overvoltage detection. The internal sourcing current of 5µA for hysteresis should be considered in the resistor divider calculation.

OVHIGH.name: OVHIGH

OVLOW.description: V LOW Overvoltage Threshold Set Pin. A resistor divider from V LOW is needed to set this threshold. When the voltage on this pin rises past the 1.2V trip point, a 5μA current is sourced out of the pin to provide externally adjustable hysteresis.

connected_components.description: A voltage divider consisting of two resistors is used to sense the V LOW voltage and present a scaled version to the OVLOW pin. The ratio of these resistors determines the overvoltage trip point. For example, to set an overvoltage threshold of 15V on V LOW, a divider can be chosen such that when V LOW = 15V, the voltage at the OVLOW pin equals 1.2V. The specific resistor values would depend on the V LOW operating range.
A small capacitor can be placed in parallel with the upper resistor of the divider to help filter noise on the V LOW line, preventing spurious overvoltage triggers.

implementation.connectivity: The OVLOW pin should be connected to a resistor divider network that senses the V LOW voltage. This divider sets the voltage presented to the OVLOW pin. The ratio of the resistors in this divider determines the specific V LOW voltage at which the overvoltage fault will be triggered.
implementation.detailed_description: The OVLOW pin is an input used to set the V LOW Overvoltage Threshold. It is part of the overvoltage protection circuitry for the V LOW output. When the voltage on this pin rises above the internal 1.2V trip point, an overvoltage condition is detected.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the OVLOW pin is to act as a set point for the V LOW overvoltage threshold. When the voltage at this pin exceeds 1.2V, it signals an overvoltage condition on the V LOW output. A 5μA hysteresis current is sourced out of this pin when the threshold is crossed, allowing for externally adjustable hysteresis. This pin is connected to the FAULT pin, which indicates the overvoltage condition.
implementation.precautions: Care must be taken when selecting the resistor values for the voltage divider connected to the OVLOW pin. The divider ratio must be set to trigger the overvoltage protection at the desired V LOW level. The 5μA hysteresis current sourced from this pin needs to be considered in the resistor selection, especially if very precise trip points are required at low V LOW voltages. Ensure the OVLOW pin is not left floating as it is an input to a comparator.

OVLOW.name: OVLOW

PGOOD.description: Power Good Indictor Output for the Regulated V HIGH /V LOW . Open drain logic out that is pulled to ground when the regulated V HIGH /V LOW exceeds ±10% regulation window, after the internal 40µS power bad mask timer expires.

connected_components.connection: Connected between the PGOOD pin and a voltage source (V5 or external bias).
connected_components.description: An external pull-up resistor is required to connect the PGOOD pin to a voltage source (e.g., V5). The value of this resistor should be chosen to ensure the pull-up current does not exceed the specified limits.

implementation.connectivity: The PGOOD pin is an open-drain output. It requires an external pull-up resistor connected to a voltage source (such as V5 or an external bias voltage) up to 6V. It is pulled low by an internal MOSFET when a fault or out-of-regulation condition occurs.

If the LTC7871 releases the PWMEN pin but it is still externally pulled down, the LTC7871 will keep all PWM pins in a high impedance (Hi-Z) status.
implementation.functionality: The PWMEN pin serves as an enable/disable signal for external gate drivers. It also acts as a status indicator for the LTC7871's operation, influencing the state of the PWM pins and potentially other LTC7871 ICs in a multi-IC system.
implementation.precautions: Ensure the external pull-up resistor is appropriately sized. If not properly pulled up, or if other LTC7871s in a multi-IC system have their PWMEN pins held low, the PWM pins may remain in a high impedance state. When the voltage on this pin is above a specific threshold, the IC's main control loop and associated internal circuits, including the DRVCC and V5 regulators, are activated. Conversely, pulling the RUN pin below this threshold initiates a controlled shutdown sequence.
implementation.functionality: The RUN pin controls the enable/disable state of the IC. It has a dynamic pull-up current: a lower current (2µA) is present when the pin is below the turn-on threshold, and this current increases to 6µA once the RUN pin rises above the 1.22V threshold. This feature facilitates a controlled start-up sequence. The RUN pin can also be externally driven directly by logic signals or pulled up via an external resistor.
implementation.precautions: Care must be taken not to exceed the absolute maximum rating of 6V on the RUN pin. When implementing a resistor divider from VHIGH for undervoltage detection, ensure the start-up voltage is appropriately set. In multiphase applications, tying RUN pins together is critical, especially for boost mode, and a clean, fast rising/falling signal is recommended for proper synchronized start-up.

Parasitic resistance, capacitance, and inductance can degrade the current sense signal and make the programmed current limit unpredictable.

SNSD4[+].name: SNSD4[+]

SNSD5[+].description: DC Positive Current Sense Comparator Inputs. These inputs amplify the DC portion of the current signal to the IC’s current comparators and current sense amplifiers.

connected_components.description: This is the component used to measure current, such as a low-value sense resistor (R_SENSE) or the DC resistance (DCR) of an inductor. It is connected between the point of current measurement and ground or a reference voltage.

These are external components used to filter the current sense signal. R1 and C1 form a low-pass filter for the AC component of the current, while R2 and C2 filter the DC component. The values are chosen based on the inductor's characteristics (L and DCR) and desired filter time constants, as detailed in the 'APPLICATIONS INFORMATION' section of the datasheet.

implementation.connectivity: The SNSD5[+] pin should be connected to the positive terminal of the current sense element (e.g., a sense resistor or the DCR of an inductor) along with the SNSA5[+] pin. Both pins should be connected through appropriate filtering networks (R1/C1 and R2/C2 as described in the datasheet) to the current sense element. The negative sense pin (SNS5[-]) should be connected to the other terminal of the current sense element, typically to V_LOW.
implementation.detailed_description: SNSD5[+] is one of the six positive DC current sense comparator inputs on the LTC7871. These inputs are designed to amplify the DC portion of the current signal, feeding it into the IC's internal current comparators and current sense amplifiers. This allows for accurate monitoring and regulation of bidirectional current flow.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of SNSD5[+] is to sense the DC component of the current. In conjunction with SNS5[-] and SNSA5[+], it forms part of the sophisticated current sensing mechanism that supports the LTC7871's advanced current mode control.
implementation.precautions: Proper PCB layout is critical for SNSD5[+] and its associated sense lines. The sense lines should be routed closely together, ideally as a Kelvin connection, to the current sense element. Filtering components must be placed very close to the IC pins to prevent noise coupling. Parasitic resistance, capacitance, and inductance in the sense lines can degrade signal integrity and affect current limit accuracy.

SNSD5[+].name: SNSD5[+]

SNSD6[+].description: DC Positive Current Sense Comparator Inputs. These inputs amplify the DC portion of the current signal to the IC’s current comparators and current sense amplifiers.

connected_components.component_name: Current Sensing Element (Inductor DCR or R_SENSE)
connected_components.description: This is the component through which the phase 6 inductor current flows. The voltage drop across this element is used to sense the current. It is connected between the SNSD6[+] and SNS6[-] pins (or rather, through the filter network to SNSD6[+] and directly to SNS6[-]).

Typically part of an RC filter network. This resistor is connected in series with the SNSD6[+] pin and the current sensing element (or its connection point). Its value is chosen in conjunction with C2 to match the L/DCR time constant of the inductor or to optimize the AC current sensing path.

Typically part of an RC filter network. This capacitor is connected from the SNSD6[+] pin to ground (or the SNS6[-] connection point). Its value is chosen in conjunction with R2 to shape the current signal and improve the signal-to-noise ratio.

implementation.connectivity: The SNSD6[+] pin should be connected to the positive terminal of the current sensing element (either DCR of the inductor or an external R_SENSE resistor) for phase 6. A filter network, typically consisting of a resistor (R2) and a capacitor (C2), is often placed between this pin and the sensing element to shape the current signal for optimal performance and noise reduction. The other end of the sensing element is connected to the SNS6[-] pin. The filter components should be placed close to the LTC7871 IC.
implementation.detailed_description: The SNSD6[+] pin is one of the positive current sense comparator inputs for the sixth phase. These inputs are designed to amplify the DC component of the current signal, providing the necessary input for the IC's current comparators and current sense amplifiers. This amplification is crucial for accurate current monitoring and regulation across all six phases of the bidirectional buck or boost operation.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as a positive input for the DC current sense amplifier and comparator for phase 6. It is part of a differential sensing mechanism along with the SNS6[-] pin to measure the current flowing through the inductor in phase 6.
implementation.precautions: The input bias current for this pin is very low (<1µA), but it is not a high impedance pin. Care must be taken to ensure proper Kelvin connections to the current sensing element. The filter components (R2, C2) should be placed as close as possible to the IC pins to minimize noise coupling. The sense lines (SNSD6[+], SNS6[-]) should be routed close together to maintain signal integrity. Floating this pin can lead to unpredictable behavior.

SS.description: Soft-Start Input. The voltage ramp rate at this pin sets the voltage ramp rate of the regulated voltage. A capacitor to ground accomplishes soft-start. This pin has a 1µA pull-up current.

connected_components.connection_details: Connected between the SS pin and SGND. The value of this capacitor sets the soft-start time (t_SOFTSTART = 1.2 * C_SS / 1µA).

implementation.connectivity: Connect an external capacitor from the SS pin to SGND to implement a soft-start function. The capacitor value determines the soft-start time.
implementation.detailed_description: The SS (Soft-Start) pin is used to control the startup ramp rate of the regulated voltage (V_LOW). It works by connecting an external capacitor to ground, which is charged by an internal 1µA pull-up current. This creates a voltage ramp on the SS pin. The LTC7871 regulates the VFB_LOW pin to the lowest of three non-inverting inputs: the internal soft-start ramp, the SS pin voltage, or the internal 1.2V reference. This allows for a smooth rise of the V_LOW voltage from zero to its final set value.
implementation.functionality: The SS pin primarily controls the soft-start process for V_LOW regulation. In boost mode, it also influences the start-up, though its effectiveness is limited until the output voltage reaches the input voltage level. When the RUN pin is pulled low or V5 drops below its UVLO threshold, the SS pin is internally pulled low by a MOSFET. External circuitry can be added to discharge the soft-start capacitor during fault conditions.
implementation.precautions: In boost mode, it is recommended to start in buck mode first. If the controller is shut down (RUN pin low) or V5 enters undervoltage lockout, the SS pin is pulled low. Ensure that external circuitry properly discharges the soft-start capacitor during fault conditions if needed. For applications requiring a clean start-up after a UV_HIGH fault is cleared, a resistor divider on the RUN pin off V_HIGH can be used.

SS.name: SS

SYNC.description: Switching Frequency Synchronization or Spread Spectrum Set Pin. Applying an external clock between 60kHz to 750kHz to this pin causes the switching frequency to synchronize to the clock signal. If SYNC is low, a resistor from the FREQ pin to SGND sets the switching frequency. Tying this pin to V5 allows switching frequency spread spectrum. This pin has a 100kΩ internal resistor to ground.

connected_components.description: Used when synchronization is desired. The clock frequency should be within the 60kHz to 750kHz range.
Connect to V5 to enable spread spectrum frequency modulation.
Connect to SGND if frequency synchronization or spread spectrum modulation is not used, allowing the FREQ pin to set the operating frequency.
Required if SYNC is tied to SGND. The resistor value connected from the FREQ pin to SGND sets the switching frequency.

connectivity: For synchronization, connect an external clock source to this pin.
To enable spread spectrum, tie this pin to V5.
If not synchronizing or using spread spectrum, tie this pin to SGND to enable frequency setting via the FREQ pin.
implementation.detailed_description: The SYNC pin is used for switching frequency synchronization and spread spectrum modulation control. It allows the internal oscillator to lock onto an external clock source, or to modulate its frequency for EMI reduction.
functionality: Switching Frequency Synchronization: Applying an external clock between 60kHz to 750kHz to this pin causes the switching frequency to synchronize to the clock signal.
Spread Spectrum Modulation: Tying this pin to V5 enables switching frequency spread spectrum modulation, which varies the switching frequency to reduce EMI.
Frequency Setting (if SYNC is low): If the SYNC pin is tied to SGND, a resistor from the FREQ pin to SGND sets the switching frequency.
precautions: When synchronizing, the FREQ pin resistor should still be present to set the controller's initial switching frequency before locking to the external clock.
The LTC7871 can only be synchronized to an external clock whose frequency is within the range of the LTC7871's internal VCO (60kHz to 750kHz).
Ensure the external clock signal has appropriate input thresholds (typically > 2V for high and < 1.1V for low).
When used in multiphase applications, the CLKOUT of one LTC7871 can be connected to the SYNC pin of another to daisy-chain synchronization.

SYNC.name: SYNC

UVHIGH.description: V HIGH Undervoltage Threshold Set Pin. A resistor divider from V HIGH is needed to set this threshold. When the voltage on this pin falls below the 1.2V trip point, a 5μA current is sunk in to the pin to provide externally adjustable hysteresis.

connected_components.connection_details: A resistor divider network connecting VHIGH to the UVHIGH pin and then to SGND. The ratio of these resistors sets the undervoltage threshold.
connected_components.purpose: To set the specific undervoltage trip point for the VHIGH supply.

connected_components.connection_details: The UVHIGH pin is connected to Signal Ground (SGND) through the lower resistor of the voltage divider.
connected_components.purpose: To establish the reference for the undervoltage detection.

implementation.connectivity: The UVHIGH pin should be connected to VHIGH through an external resistor divider. The resistor divider is used to set the specific undervoltage trip point. The value of the resistor divider components determines the voltage at which the UVHIGH pin trips the comparator.
implementation.detailed_description: The UVHIGH pin is used to set the undervoltage threshold for the VHIGH supply. When the voltage on this pin falls below the internal comparator threshold of 1.2V, the undervoltage condition is detected.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as an input to an undervoltage comparator. When the voltage at this pin falls below 1.2V, the comparator trips. The device then sinks a 5µA current into this pin to provide externally adjustable hysteresis, which helps to prevent oscillation during undervoltage events.
implementation.precautions: Care must be taken when selecting the resistor divider values to ensure the desired undervoltage threshold is accurately set. The 5µA hysteresis current sunk into this pin by the comparator must be accounted for in the resistor divider calculation.

UVHIGH.name: UVHIGH

V5.description: Internal 5V Regulator Output. The control circuits are powered from this voltage. Bypass this pin to SGND with a minimum of 4.7µF low ESR tantalum or ceramic capacitor.

connected_components.details: A minimum of 4.7μF low ESR tantalum or ceramic capacitor is required for bypassing. An additional 0.1μF ceramic capacitor is recommended for improved noise filtering. These capacitors should be connected between the V5 pin and the SGND pin.

implementation.connectivity: The V5 pin should be bypassed to ground with a minimum of a 4.7μF low ESR tantalum or ceramic capacitor. It is also recommended to place an additional 0.1μF ceramic capacitor directly adjacent to the V5 and SGND pins for improved noise filtering.
implementation.detailed_description: The V5 pin is the output of an internal 5V linear regulator. This regulator supplies power to most of the internal circuitry of the LTC7871, including the control logic and error amplifiers. It is crucial for the proper operation of the IC.
implementation.functionality: The V5 pin provides a regulated 5V supply for the internal circuitry. It is generated by an internal linear regulator that takes its input from the DRVCC pin. The V5 rail is essential for powering the IC's core functions. Additionally, the V5 pin is used as a logic supply for various digital I/O pins like CSB, SCLK, SDI, SDO, PWM outputs, and others. It also serves as a reference voltage for certain internal comparators and thresholds.
implementation.precautions: The V5 regulator requires a minimum input voltage from DRVCC (typically 6V) to operate correctly. If DRVCC drops below its undervoltage lockout (UVLO) threshold, the V5 regulator will also be disabled, leading to a shutdown of the IC. Proper bypassing of the V5 pin is critical to ensure stable operation and prevent noise from affecting the internal circuitry.

V5.name: V5

VFBHIGH.description: V HIGH Voltage Sensing Error Amplifier Noninverting Input.

connected_components.description: Typically, two resistors form a voltage divider network to sample the VHIGH output voltage. These resistors are connected between VHIGH, VFBHIGH, and SGND. The ratio of these resistors determines the regulated VHIGH voltage. For example, R_D from VHIGH to VFBHIGH and R_C from VFBHIGH to SGND, where VHIGH = 1.2V * (1 + R_D / R_C).
The MFR_IDAC_VHIGH register in the SPI interface can be used to inject current into or sink current from the VFBHIGH pin, allowing for programmable voltage margining of the VHIGH output.

implementation.connectivity: In a typical application schematic, the VFBHIGH pin is connected to a voltage divider network that samples the VHIGH output voltage. This divider sets the feedback loop's reference point.  It is also connected to the SPI interface for voltage margining capabilities.
implementation.detailed_description: The VFBHIGH pin is the non-inverting input for the error amplifier responsible for regulating the VHIGH voltage.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of VFBHIGH is to sense the VHIGH voltage. It serves as the feedback input to the voltage error amplifier that controls the VHIGH output. The voltage on this pin is compared to an internal reference voltage to regulate VHIGH.  In boost mode, this pin is actively used for voltage regulation. In buck mode, while it's a feedback pin, the primary voltage regulation is handled by VFB LOW. However, VFBHIGH can still be used for output voltage margining in boost mode via the SPI interface.
implementation.precautions: The feedback path to VFBHIGH should be kept away from noisy switching nodes (like the SW pins) and carefully routed to minimize noise pickup. The voltage divider resistors should be chosen for accuracy (e.g., 1% tolerance) as they directly set the output voltage.  When VHIGH is being regulated, ensure that the voltage on VFBHIGH is within the IC's operating range.

VFBHIGH.name: VFBHIGH

VFBLOW.description: V LOW Voltage Sensing Error Amplifier Inverting Input.

connected_components.description: Two resistors form a voltage divider to sense the V_LOW output voltage and provide a scaled feedback signal to the VFB_LOW pin. The ratio of these resistors determines the target V_LOW output voltage.  One resistor connects from V_LOW to the VFB_LOW pin, and the other connects from the VFB_LOW pin to SGND.

An external capacitor connected from the SS pin to SGND allows for a programmed soft-start ramp. During soft-start, the VFB_LOW pin will track the voltage on the SS pin until it reaches the internal reference.
A capacitor connected between the VFB_LOW and ITH_LOW pins to compensate the voltage error amplifier loop, improving stability and transient response.

implementation.connectivity: The VFB_LOW pin should be connected to the junction of the voltage divider resistors that sense the V_LOW output. A feedback capacitor (e.g., CFF1) is typically connected between the VFB_LOW pin and the ITH_LOW pin for loop compensation. During soft-start, an external capacitor may be connected from the SS pin to SGND, and the VFB_LOW pin will track the SS pin voltage until it reaches the internal reference.  For margining, the DAC output current (controlled by MFR_IDAC_VLOW via the SPI interface) is injected into or sunk from this pin.
implementation.detailed_description: The VFB_LOW pin is the inverting input of the error amplifier responsible for regulating the V_LOW voltage. It receives the feedback signal from the output voltage divider. The error amplifier compares this feedback signal to an internal reference voltage (typically 1.2V) and adjusts the ITH_LOW voltage to control the peak inductor current, thereby regulating the V_LOW output.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the VFB_LOW pin is to serve as the inverting input for the V_LOW voltage regulation error amplifier. Its voltage level directly influences the control loop that maintains the V_LOW output at the desired setpoint.  It can also be influenced by the SS (Soft-Start) pin during startup, allowing for controlled voltage ramping. In the context of the SPI interface, the MFR_IDAC_VLOW register can inject current into or sink current from the VFB_LOW pin to adjust the V_LOW voltage (margining).
implementation.precautions: Proper placement of the feedback voltage divider resistors is crucial to minimize noise pickup. The feedback trace from the V_LOW output to the VFB_LOW pin should be routed away from switching nodes (like the SW pins) and noisy components (like inductors) to ensure signal integrity. The feedback loop compensation components (e.g., CFF1) should be placed as close as possible to the IC pins.  Care must be taken when using the SPI interface to adjust the V_LOW voltage via the MFR_IDAC_VLOW register, as incorrect settings could lead to instability or damage.

VFBLOW.name: VFBLOW

VHIGH.description: Main V HIGH Supply. Bypass this pin to ground with a capacitor (0.1μF to 1μF).

connected_components.connection: Connected between VHIGH pin and SGND (ground plane).
connected_components.details: Typically a 0.1µF to 1µF ceramic or tantalum capacitor with low ESR. This capacitor helps to filter out noise and ensure a stable supply voltage to the IC.
This is the primary voltage source for the system, which can be as high as 100V.

implementation.connectivity: VHIGH should be connected to the positive terminal of the main power source. It requires a bypass capacitor connected between the VHIGH pin and the ground plane. This bypass capacitor should be placed as close as possible to the VHIGH pin for optimal performance. The value of the bypass capacitor is typically between 0.1µF and 1µF.
implementation.detailed_description: VHIGH is the main supply voltage input for the LTC7871. This pin powers the internal circuitry of the controller, including the gate drivers and control logic. It can accept voltages up to 100V, making it suitable for high-voltage applications. Proper bypassing is crucial for stable operation.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of VHIGH is to supply power to the LTC7871. It serves as the main input voltage rail. In some configurations, it can also be used as a reference for overvoltage and undervoltage protection circuits connected to the OVHIGH and UVHIGH pins, respectively.
implementation.precautions: Ensure that the voltage applied to the VHIGH pin does not exceed its absolute maximum rating of 100V. Overvoltage can damage the IC. Proper bypassing with a low ESR capacitor is critical to prevent noise and ensure stable operation, especially during switching transients. For applications where VHIGH might drop significantly, consider the undervoltage lockout (UVLO) thresholds for the RUN pin to ensure controlled startup.
